urls.title: 10 Key Reading Practices for All Middle and High Schools - The Meadows Center
urls.description: Description The fourth installment of MCPER’s “10 Key” series, this document distills the latest research findings into 10 easy-to-follow recommendations that states, school districts, and schools can use to improve middle and high school students’ reading outcomes. Also included are descriptions of what students should know and be able to do at selected secondary grade levels.

urls.title: Student retention and third-grade reading: It’s about the adults
urls.description: Improving reading results, especially for Black and Hispanic students, is one of our top educational priorities. The numbers are dire, as we see almost half of these youngsters performing “Below Basic” on the fourth grade NAEP—a truly alarming level of performance.

data.text: @karenvaites @RacheGabriel @DrMPaff @CAParentPower @LDH_ed @careads @mgpotente @HKorbey @mpolikoff @ChadAldeman Maybe this is the one you’re referring to @karenvaites https://t.co/HFeLy8r0Mz

@karenvaites @RacheGabriel @DrMPaff @CAParentPower @LDH_ed @careads @mgpotente @HKorbey @mpolikoff @ChadAldeman Well, MS didn’t retain any Ss in 3rd grade last year based on LBPA (2021), and they (2022 4th graders) held their own on NAEP reading,even scoring above the national avg for the 1st time (still so much work to do, though). I guess we can “debunk” the retention theory, huh?

urls.title: LAUSD superintendent joins experts in supporting pursuit of science of reading | EdSource
urls.description: Alberto M. Carvalho emigrated to the United States from Portugal as a penniless 17-year-old with little knowledge of English. Now the superintendent of Los Angeles Unified, the nation’s second-largest school dist rict, he is championing California’s pursuit o f the science of reading amid the literacy crisis. “I’m a science devotee,” said Carvalho, who boosted reading scores in Miami through research-based practices before decamping to California, during his opening rem arks Wednesday at the an nual

data.text: “Being in Mississippi, the poorest state in the nation, we finally got to a point where we had adults on the same page about what was really in our power to do in public education,” said Burk. #earlyliteracy @careads @ExcelinEd https://t.co/IJaA8augSB

urls.title: Sold a Story: How Teaching Kids to Read Went So Wrong
urls.description: There's an idea about how children learn to read that's held sway in schools for more than a generation — even though it was proven wrong by cognitive scientists decades ago. Teaching methods based on this idea can make it harder for children to learn how to read. In this new podcast, host Emily Hanford investigates the influential authors who promote this idea and the company that sells their work. It's an expose of how educators came to believe in something that isn't true and are now reckoning with the consequences — children harmed, money wasted, an education system upended.

urls.title: Right to Read and Literacy in New Haven
urls.description: It was an exciting night for proponents of Connecticut’s “Right to Read” legislation. In an event hosted by New Haven Reads at the Barack H. Obama Magnet University School, over two hundred people gathered in-person—and over three hundred more tuned in on the live stream—to hear from national literacy experts Emily Hanford (American Public Media) and Kymyona Burk (ExcelinEd). Also featured were Dr. Margie Gillis (Literacy How), Dr. Tamu Lucero (Stamford Public Schools), Amy Dowell, and Ashley St

urls.title: How Mississippi Reformed Reading Instruction | George W. Bush Presidential Center
urls.description: A Conversation with Kymyona Burk, Senior Policy Fellow, ExcelinEd By passing education reform legislation, Mississippi took an important first step toward prioritizing reading achievement. But full support – adequate infrastructure, capacity, and funding – is critical to ensuring success. After years of struggling with student reading deficits, Mississippi legislators made history in 2013 by passing the Literacy-Based Promotion Act. For the first time, Mississippi had a state-led, comprehensive approach

We knew @hechingerreport was publishing the letter. We supported them publishing it. We don't think the letter accurately described our reporting. So our editor @C_E_Winter pointed that out in her response. 2/3

Hey all. I see people criticizing @hechingerreport for publishing that letter. Some context.
We got the letter too. We (@apmreports)
don't publish Letters to Editor. Hechinger does. It made sense for them to publish. They partnered w/ us to publish Sold a Story on their site. 1/3

urls.title: OPINION: A call for rejecting the newest reading wars
urls.description: Fifty-eight educators say ‘Sold a Story’ podcast series sells incomplete story about reading instruction

tweets.text: I think it's a good thing to get views out in the open. Let people speak for themselves. You can judge and critique and agree or disagree. @hechingerreport did the right thing here. https://t.co/kLzyUB7rHv  @nicholedobo @L_willen 3/3

urls.title: Want to know more about the science of reading?
urls.description: Here’s a reading list put together by Emily Hanford, host and lead producer of our podcast Sold a Story: How Teaching Kids to Read Went So Wrong.

urls.title: Heinemann’s billion-dollar sales have nationwide reach
urls.description: APM Reports found that the controversial educational publishing company has sold instructional materials and professional resources in almost every state, earning at least $1.6 billion over a decade.

tweets.text:
🧵on why the map of Heinemann sales matters.

Take the dot of San Francisco Unified, for example...

urls.title: Sen. Muth Announces $125k Grant to Fund Decodable Book Collections in SD44 Libraries
urls.description: ROYERSFORD, November 4, 2022: State Sen. Katie Muth (D-Chester/Montgomery/Berks) today announced a $125,000 grant to establish a collection of decodable books in every public library across Senate District 44.

tweets.text: We are so excited to share this announcement from @SenatorMuth! https://t.co/sNGGf3kKF9 Bringing the SOR to Eastern PA!! Decodable text is one important piece of the process for emergent readers. Families can pair decodable text with language experiences to support early readers.

urls.title: Sold a Story: How Teaching Kids to Read Went So Wrong
urls.description: There's an idea about how children learn to read that's held sway in schools for more than a generation — even though it was proven wrong by cognitive scientists decades ago. Teaching methods based on this idea can make it harder for children to learn how to read. In this new podcast, host Emily Hanford investigates the influential authors who promote this idea and the company that sells their work. It's an expose of how educators came to believe in something that isn't true and are now reckoning with the consequences — children harmed, money wasted, an education system upended.

tweets.text:
Our new podcast, Sold a Story, is out.
Listen wherever you get your podcasts. 
Or go to our website.
https://t.co/DKZqVrd5y7 https://t.co/ksLOK90YIS

urls.title: 85% of Mississippi 3rd graders pass reading assessment for 2021-22 school year | The Mississippi Department of Education
urls.description: For Immediate Release: October 27, 2022 JACKSON, Miss. – Today, the Mississippi Department of Education (MDE) announced that, despite pandemic disruptions to learning, 85% of Mississippi 3rd graders passed the 3rd-grade reading assessment after final retests for the 2021-22 school year. The 2021-22 pass rate is practically the same as it was in 2018-19 when 86% of 3rd graders passed the assessment. The assessment was not administered in 2019-20 due to COVID-19. The assessment was administered once in

tweets.text: Sound literacy policy rooted in the science of reading is paying off due to the efforts of teachers and students in Mississippi. Congrats! #literacymatters ⁦@MissDeptEd⁩ ⁦@kymyona_burk⁩  https://t.co/hzaTW0lVpT

Hearing about the importance of literacy coaches in helping struggling students learn to read at the Virginia Education Summit as part of my work as a member of the House Education Committee. #VAEdSummit @kymyona_burk @EmilySolari @MSReads1
@kymyona_burk @Hunt_Institute @ExcelinEd @CarrieCoyner So glad to benefit from your insights today, @kymyona_burk. #VES22 #VAEdSummit @Hunt_Institute

In 2022, the Virginia Literacy Act grounded literacy instruction in science-based reading research. 

After an introduction from @CarrieCoyner, Kelly Butler of @MSReads1, @kymyona_burk, & @emilyjsolari, discuss how to ensure quality implementation of this bill. #VES22 #VAEdSummit https://t.co/9mEvCh381w
Just follow Mississippi’s plans, practice and results.  SOR.  Thanks @MissDeptEd @ExcelinAction @kymyona_burk good stories to tell & good outcomes to report. https://t.co/cXnAQDqOQR

urls.title: Mississippi maintains NAEP 4th grade reading gains despite national decline in all subjects | The Mississippi Department of Education
urls.description: For Immediate Release: Oct. 24, 2022 JACKSON, Miss. – Mississippi maintained its historic gains in 4th grade reading on the 2022 National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), while scores nationally dropped in all four NAEP subjects and grades. The 2022 NAEP results provide the first national measure of student learning since the start of the pandemic. Known as the Nation’s Report Card, NAEP measures student performance in 4th and 8th grade reading and math in all 50 states and Washington, D.C.

tweets.text: Mississippi maintained its historic gains in 4th grade reading on the 2022 National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), while scores nationally dropped in all four NAEP subjects and grades. Get details at https://t.co/xYleeemvjk.  #MsEdu https://t.co/XVRV8VG8Pj

I can't stop looking at this NAEP stuff.

Louisiana teachers lifted kids out of Below Basic while weathering multiple hurricanes and a pandemic.

I have a few words for these Science of Reading critics, and as they say in Jersey City, "they ain't Happy Birthday."  😆 https://t.co/TH6O6vX8Eb

@SarahDSparks @JebBush @LevesquePat .@kymyona_burk would like to see states invest in teachers and “bolster the use of science-based reading instruction to help students who started school during the pandemic and may struggle more with foundational reading skills.”

“Kids need more time,” said @LevesquePat the CEO of ExcelinEd, in a briefing before the NAEP results were released. “They lost time over the last several years, of getting instruction that they need in math, and we need to figure out ways to give them more time.”

urls.title: Two Decades of Progress, Nearly Gone: National Math, Reading Scores Hit Historic Lows
urls.description: The pandemic has smacked 4th and 8th graders back to the last century in math and reading, according to new national assessments.

tweets.text: “This is not just nerdy education policy stuff. This is really about the future of young people. The world we’re moving towards is one that requires significantly higher skills to be successful, to live lives of purpose and meaning,” - @JebBush https://t.co/SCOZp4XFJn

“We have to invest in people, we have to invest in their knowledge,” said @kymyona_burk.
Burk added states need to bolster the use of science-based reading instruction to help students who started school during the pandemic and may struggle more with foundational reading skills.
When you’re presenting @kymyona_burk an award, it feels like  you’re also getting an award.  ❤️🥇❤️🏆 https://t.co/pAez2OqXzi

urls.title: Credentials matter, but pathways matter more
urls.description: Credentials matter, but maybe not as much as many hope. That seems to be one of the takeaways from Fordham’s latest report by Matt Giani evaluating high school industry recognized credential (IRC) attainment and learner outcomes in Texas.
